Award.AwardTitle: SII Planning: WHISPERS: Wireless Hardware Innovations and Signal Processing for Enhanced Radio-astronomy and Scientific Spectrum Sharing
Award.AbstractNarration: This award is a planning grant for the Spectrum Innovation Initiative: National Center for Wireless Spectrum Research (SII-Center). The focus of a spectrum research SII-Center goes beyond 5G, IoT, and other existing or forthcoming systems and technologies to chart out a trajectory to ensure United States leadership in future wireless technologies, systems, and applications in science and engineering through the efficient use and sharing of the radio spectrum. The extraordinary growth of wireless communication, navigation, and radar systems has resulted in a convergence of scientific, commercial, and defense interests competing for access to RF and millimeter wave spectrum. There is mounting pressure on regulators and stakeholders to find mutually beneficial ways to share this spectrum, including bands where scientists have so far had unfettered access. A partnership comprising such complexity and scale is a grand challenge. The stakes are high and the opportunities unprecedented and potentially transformative. The objective of this project is to lay out a strategic framework and coalesce a comprehensive center-scale team that will engage and harness the forces competing for access to this precious resource. This project’s vision is to catalyze a vibrant community of world-class scientists and engineers in academia, industry, government agencies, and regulatory authorities, to create a hub for sustained research, technologies, and innovation.<br/><br/>This project is aimed at the development of a comprehensive plan for a national center which would help maintain and extend US leadership in future wireless technologies, systems, and applications in science and engineering through the efficient use and sharing of radio spectrum from sub-6 GHz to well beyond 100 GHz. The project team is led by the University of Virginia (UVA), with partners at Northwestern University (NU), the National Radio-Astronomy Observatory’s (NRAO) Central Development Lab (CDL), and Virginia Diodes, Inc. (VDI). They propose to employ machine learning techniques, develop nonlinear receiving metrology tools, as well as approaches to spectrum management designed to protect science applications in poor signal-to-noise and signal-to-interference environments. Planning activities include research topics such as hardware development and design, as well as partnerships for broadening participation. This award will include education and workforce development, such as the development of a spectrum engineering certificate, curriculum, citizen science projects, and broadening participation efforts in spectrum through partnerships with Historically Black Colleges and Universities and other minority-serving institutions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The initial objective of the Whispers effort centered on developing a strategic framework and the consolidating a center-scale team to engage and harness the talents and knowledge of stakeholders competing for access to and use of the electromagnetic spectrum. This original vision was to catalyze a vibrant community of world-class scientists and engineers in academia, industry, government agencies, and regulatory authorities, to create a hub for sustained research, technologies, and innovation from sub-6 GHz to 1 THz. Building on this vision through support of this planning grant, the Whispers team engaged in comprehensive discussions and planning with a number of competing teams with complementary expertise and focus, resulting in a more comprehensive team that expanded on the original goals of protection of passive scientific sensing and development of millimeter-wave metrology and instrumentation  This effort involved many months of discussion, planning meetings, organization, collection of information and  formulation of a vision for a center that addressed a broad range existing and emerging issues in spectrum coexistence.  The outcome of this effort was a merging of the Whispers planning grant team with reciprocal efforts at the University of Notre Dame (NCRSI, Nick Laneman, PI), the University of Colorado (WISE, Scott Palo, PI) and Olin College (OSIIC, Whitney Lohmeyer, PI). Through this process, the vision and organization for a center, known as "SpectrumX," was developed that included leaders spanning a fuller range of uses, applications, and technologies for radio spectrum access and sharing. The merged team included experts in astronomy and earth sensing technologies, military and commercial uses of the spectrum, spectrum economics and regulatory policy, data, instrumentation and sensing.

 

Intellectual Merit: The primary intellectual merit of the work done under the Whispers planning grant consisted of the engagement of stakeholder communities that were diverse, specialized and spanned different technical/scientific domains. The intellectual promise in cultivating the fertile ground between these diverse groups by encouraging interdisciplinary collaboration between them, and initiating preliminary research efforts to address fundamental issues in spectrum access are central to the merit of this work. In addition, the merit associated with initial research efforts supported by the grant that were aimed to develop new millimeter-wave metrology tools, wideband sensing and interference tagging approaches, agile coexistence via scientific schedule sharing, and re-purposing of very low-power RF integrated circuits for a comprehensive citizen-science project support the fundamental aims of discovering new avenues that allow shared spectrum access between diverse users.

 

Broader Impacts: In addition to the spectrum engineering workforce and educational development efforts explored during the planning process, the Whispers planning efforts benefited from leveraging NRAO?s strong partnerships with Historically Black Colleges and Universities and other minority-serving institutions to broaden participation, forming a central core of the SpectrumX center that grew from the planning effort.
